skills.name: Represent a linear inequality with a single tail on a number line
Given the representation of a linear inequality with a single tail on a number line, express it using inequality notation
Form inequalities from situations described in words

explanations.A: Very close but if she has $75, then she can spend exactly $75 too! What inequality symbol could show this?
explanations.B: I think you've got your inequality symbols mixed up. This statement says that the dress + shoes must be greater than $75 which it can't be if she only has $75 to spend!
explanations.C: If she has $75 to spend, the total cost of what she buys must be less than or equal to 75.
explanations.D: I think you've got your inequality symbols mixed up. This statement says that the dress + shoes must be greater than or equal to $75 which it can't be if she only has $75 to spend!

explanations.A: I think you've got your inequality symbols mixed up. This statement says that the skirt + tops must be greater than or equal to $95 which it can't be if she only has $95 to spend!
explanations.B: If she has $95 to spend, the total cost of what she buys must be less than or equal to 95.
explanations.C: Very close but if she has $95, then she can spend exactly $95 too! What inequality symbol could show this?
explanations.D: I think you've got your inequality symbols mixed up. This statement says that the skirt + tops must be greater than $95 which it can't be if she only has $95 to spend!

explanations.A: If the circle is colored in, it means it can include the value it is on too!
explanations.B: The direction of the arrow tells us the solution set is less than -2. The question is asking about the circle...
explanations.C: If the circle is colored in (closed), it means it can include the value it is on too, meaning this inequality could include -2!
explanations.D: Not quite - the circle tells us whether to include the number it is above in the set or not. The circle is colored in here, what do you think that means?

explanations.A: The direction of the arrow tells us the solution set is less than 3. The question is asking about the circle...
explanations.B: Not quite - the circle tells us whether to include the number it is above in the set or not. The circle is colored in here, what do you think that means?
explanations.C: If the circle is colored in (closed), it means it can include the value it is on too, meaning this inequality could include 3!
explanations.D: If the circle is colored in, it means it can include the value it is on too!

explanations.A: If the circle is colored in (closed), it means it can include the value it is on too. The arrow is going up the number line, showing greater values. That means the inequality symbol would be ≥, greater than or equal to.
explanations.B: I think you've got your inequality symbols mixed up. ≤ means less than or equal to. Is the arrow pointing to values less than -3?
explanations.C: If the circle is colored in (closed), it means it can include the value it is on too! How could we show that with an inequality symbol?
explanations.D: I think you've got your inequality symbols mixed up. < means less than. Is the arrow pointing to values less than -3?

explanations.A: If the circle is colored in (closed), it means it can include the value it is on too! How could we show that with an inequality symbol?
explanations.B: I think you've got your inequality symbols mixed up. < means less than. Is the arrow pointing to values less than 0?
explanations.C: If the circle is colored in (closed), it means it can include the value it is on too. The arrow is going up the number line, showing greater values. That means the inequality symbol would be ≥, greater than or equal to.
explanations.D: I think you've got your inequality symbols mixed up. ≤ means less than or equal to. Is the arrow pointing to values less than 0?

explanations.A: Look at the arrow. The inequality is done from the number where the circle is, following the direction of the arrow...
explanations.B: Look at the arrow. The inequality is done from the number where the circle is, following the direction of the arrow...
explanations.C: The arrow is pointing to values less than 4, and the circle is open which means it can't include the value it is on. Therefore, the correct inequality symbol is < which is less than, not equal to.
explanations.D: If the circle is open (not colored in), it means it cannot include the value it is on too! How could we show that with an inequality symbol?

explanations.A: The arrow is pointing to values less than -1 and the circle is open which means it can't include the value it is on. Therefore, the correct inequality symbol is < which is less than, not equal to.
explanations.B: I think you've got your inequality symbols mixed up. ≥ means greater than or equal to. Is the arrow pointing to values greater than -1?
explanations.C: If the circle is open (not colored in), it means it cannot include the value it is on too! How could we show that with an inequality symbol?
explanations.D: I think you've got your inequality symbols mixed up. > means greater than. Is the arrow pointing to values greater than -1?

explanations.A: If the circle is open (not colored in), it means it cannot include the value it is on too! The symbol ≥ means it can also be equal to the value, how could we show that on a number line?
explanations.B: The arrow is pointing to values greater than -1 and the circle is closed, which means it can include the value it is on. This matches the inequality symbol ≥ which is 'greater than or equal to'
explanations.C: The arrow here is pointing to values less than -1, but the ≥ symbol means greater than or equal to...
explanations.D: The arrow here is pointing to values less than -1, but the ≥ symbol means greater than or equal to.

explanations.A: The arrow here is pointing to values less than 1, but the ≥ symbol means greater than or equal to.
explanations.B: The arrow here is pointing to values less than 1, but the ≥ symbol means greater than or equal to...
explanations.C: The arrow is pointing to values greater than 1 and the circle is closed, which means it can include the value it is on. This matches the inequality symbol ≥ which is 'greater than or equal to'
explanations.D: If the circle is open (not colored in), it means it cannot include the value it is on too! The symbol ≥ means it can also be equal to the value, how could we show that on a number line?
